BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 26, 1923

NOW, THEN—
We told you so! We can certainly say that now in real indignation. Two months ago we published an editorial bewailing the fact
that our main thoroughfare, from Thirty-second street to Gilman
Hall, was far too narrow, that pedestrians were forced to walk upon
the sodded portions bordering the road in order to avoid being hit.
We pointed out that, unless the automobile traffic was diverted to a
temporary road, in the rear of the engineering buildings, snow-time
would again catch us doing the artful-dodger stunt.
"We told you so!" Came the winter; came the rain, slush, automobile slopping at thirty miles an hour along our ribbon of road!
Jump! Jump in the soft, piled melting snow or be covered with flying slush. Nice comfortable means of travel, that! Bah! Why didn't
you run those machines in the rear'of the engineering building while
the sun shone? There would have been at least some sort of road
thereby now.
A crown of glory to the organization that brings us this bit of
relief! Omicron Delta Kappa should be able to accomplish it. Or
perhaps Sigma Chi Beta could post.a large "Please" sign across the
Thirty-second street entrance. What can the faculty expect of us
with cold feet? Hot feet, cool head; yes, and cold feet, hot head!
Of course, this is only the second warning, but we may not be
able to "come up for the third time.' By then we will probably be at
home with our feet in mustard-water, our chests under plasters and
our throats smelling of oil, in which case we will hoarsely warn for
the third time, "I told you—a-a-chew !"
Or the third time may find us 'pushing up sod in some nearby
cemetery, in which case we will certainly have embroidered on our
tombstone,
I told you so."

PROGRESS
A new era in Hopkins field of dramatics will be entered upon, if
the latest idea of the Dramatic Club is successful. It has long been
the dream of many who are connected with the club, particularly its
coach, to be able to present an all-Hopkins performance, either in
straight comedy or its musical variation.
The proposal to present a burlesque on "The Purple Mask" as a
part of the June Week program has been enthusiastically accepted.
A number of ideas have been contributed and from all appearances
the proposition looks like a real possibility.
Any student who has no ability at the interpretative end of dramatics, but who is clever at writing or framing such a burlesque, will
find a welcome awaiting him at the club's studio in the Barn.

INTERFRATERNITY BOARD
DEFEATS PROPOSED
AMENDMENTS
Chapter Pictures Are to Be in
Group Form.
The suggested amendment to
the constitution of the Interfraternity- Board which provided that a
favorable vote of three-fourths of
the representatives be sufficient
to pass an amendment to the constitution or to change the rushing agreement was defeated at the
regular meeting of the board last
Monday at 12.20 P. M. The present system requires a negative
vote of only two of the fraternities
to defeat an amendment or a motion.
It was moved also that the required number of votes for defeat
of a measure be raised from two
to three. This motion was defeated.
It was decided in addition that
the board should go on record as
approving the group. type of pictures of the various chapters for
the Hullabaloo, such as were
used in last year's Hullabaloo
There has been some agitation in
favor of small oval pictures of the
individual members of each chapter all to be printed on the same
Page. It was also decided that the
board should put no limit on the
amount of space that each fraternity may have in the Hullabaloo.

The Engineering in a Curling Iron
What sort of engineering' is it that
makes a study of the needs and the
interests of women and creates products to satisfy them? Does it seem
that, in practice at least, this sort of
thing is a little different from your
understanding of what an engineer
really is and does?
After all,.when you come to think of
it, engineering is concerned with all
the facts of life. It takes the old facts
and interprets them in new and
broader ways; but its big job is the
very big job of making more living,
—fuller living,—readily available. It
is, in every aspect, a thing worth doing, whether it concerns itself with
curling irons or converters, or any of
the thousands of products in between.
This is truly the day of the engineer. His judgments and his equip-

ment are sought in almost every phase
of living. Engineering is remaking the
business of housekeeping. Its methods
are being applied to merchandising, to distribution, to the wrapping of
bundles and the packing of boxes, to
the lighting of streets and the hundreds of things that, a few years
back, were strictly "rule-of-thumb".
By the time you are at work out in
the world, there will be more—though
there are only a few of them left.
Whatever is worth doing is worth
engineering; engineering effort dignifies itself. Whether it puts more usefulness into transformers or curling
irons or turbines does not matter.
The thing that counts is the work, the
creative, constructive service that is
going on for the lasting benefit of
mankind.

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 26, 1923

NOW, THEN—
We told you so! We can certainly say that now in real indignation. Two months ago we published an editorial bewailing the fact
that our main thoroughfare, from Thirty-second street to Gilman
Hall, was far too narrow, that pedestrians were forced to walk upon
the sodded portions bordering the road in order to avoid being hit.
We pointed out that, unless the automobile traffic was diverted to a
temporary road, in the rear of the engineering buildings, snow-time
would again catch us doing the artful-dodger stunt.
"We told you so!" Came the winter; came the rain, slush, automobile slopping at thirty miles an hour along our ribbon of road!
Jump! Jump in the soft, piled melting snow or be covered with flying slush. Nice comfortable means of travel, that! Bah! Why didn't
you run those machines in the rear'of the engineering building while
the sun shone? There would have been at least some sort of road
thereby now.
A crown of glory to the organization that brings us this bit of
relief! Omicron Delta Kappa should be able to accomplish it. Or
perhaps Sigma Chi Beta could post.a large "Please" sign across the
Thirty-second street entrance. What can the faculty expect of us
with cold feet? Hot feet, cool head; yes, and cold feet, hot head!
Of course, this is only the second warning, but we may not be
able to "come up for the third time.' By then we will probably be at
home with our feet in mustard-water, our chests under plasters and
our throats smelling of oil, in which case we will hoarsely warn for
the third time, "I told you—a-a-chew !"
Or the third time may find us 'pushing up sod in some nearby
cemetery, in which case we will certainly have embroidered on our
tombstone,
I told you so."

PROGRESS
A new era in Hopkins field of dramatics will be entered upon, if
the latest idea of the Dramatic Club is successful. It has long been
the dream of many who are connected with the club, particularly its
coach, to be able to present an all-Hopkins performance, either in
straight comedy or its musical variation.
The proposal to present a burlesque on "The Purple Mask" as a
part of the June Week program has been enthusiastically accepted.
A number of ideas have been contributed and from all appearances
the proposition looks like a real possibility.
Any student who has no ability at the interpretative end of dramatics, but who is clever at writing or framing such a burlesque, will
find a welcome awaiting him at the club's studio in the Barn.

INTERFRATERNITY BOARD
DEFEATS PROPOSED
AMENDMENTS
Chapter Pictures Are to Be in
Group Form.
The suggested amendment to
the constitution of the Interfraternity- Board which provided that a
favorable vote of three-fourths of
the representatives be sufficient
to pass an amendment to the constitution or to change the rushing agreement was defeated at the
regular meeting of the board last
Monday at 12.20 P. M. The present system requires a negative
vote of only two of the fraternities
to defeat an amendment or a motion.
It was moved also that the required number of votes for defeat
of a measure be raised from two
to three. This motion was defeated.
It was decided in addition that
the board should go on record as
approving the group. type of pictures of the various chapters for
the Hullabaloo, such as were
used in last year's Hullabaloo
There has been some agitation in
favor of small oval pictures of the
individual members of each chapter all to be printed on the same
Page. It was also decided that the
board should put no limit on the
amount of space that each fraternity may have in the Hullabaloo.

The Engineering in a Curling Iron
What sort of engineering' is it that
makes a study of the needs and the
interests of women and creates products to satisfy them? Does it seem
that, in practice at least, this sort of
thing is a little different from your
understanding of what an engineer
really is and does?
After all,.when you come to think of
it, engineering is concerned with all
the facts of life. It takes the old facts
and interprets them in new and
broader ways; but its big job is the
very big job of making more living,
—fuller living,—readily available. It
is, in every aspect, a thing worth doing, whether it concerns itself with
curling irons or converters, or any of
the thousands of products in between.
This is truly the day of the engineer. His judgments and his equip-

ment are sought in almost every phase
of living. Engineering is remaking the
business of housekeeping. Its methods
are being applied to merchandising, to distribution, to the wrapping of
bundles and the packing of boxes, to
the lighting of streets and the hundreds of things that, a few years
back, were strictly "rule-of-thumb".
By the time you are at work out in
the world, there will be more—though
there are only a few of them left.
Whatever is worth doing is worth
engineering; engineering effort dignifies itself. Whether it puts more usefulness into transformers or curling
irons or turbines does not matter.
The thing that counts is the work, the
creative, constructive service that is
going on for the lasting benefit of
mankind.
